1) I am replying to an existing topic and I just click on any message from that topic and reply.
2) If I am starting a new topic. I click on any topic and reply, but I create a new topic. I don't worry about finding the right topic. If I am not replying to anything, then it's a new topic (if my new topic happens to align with an old existing topic, that is fine, but it's not required).

I've noticed in the past that we store the number of languages in "language_count" within system.core.json. That seems odd to me, but I have not asked till now... in most cases, where the Language module has not been enabled at all, it's safe to assume only a single language; right? So, I was wondering why do we need to store the language count in config, when we can do something like:

$language_count = module_exists('language') ? count(language_list(TRUE)) : 1;

Is reading from the filesystem/config faster than the above?
Short answer is yes
It doesn't need to check all module records
still strange tho

OK, I'm shutting up then :sweat_smile: ... @Herb I think I see what you mean: module_exists() seems to be calling module_list(), which in turn may call functions like backdrop_get_filename() or system_list() ...which seem to be reading from the filesystem ...but as @docwilmot said, still strange from a non-Drupal/Backdrop developer PoV.

There can be more than one language even for single language sites. Sites that have a default language that's not English still have English installed (of course) in addition to the actual default language in use. OK, English could get disabled, but that's not necessarily always the case.

Putting language_count and language_default in config provides a fast way to access this information (compared to calling functions).
